Award.AwardTitle: Layer-Structured Semiconductor Alloys: Growth, Characterization, and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This research project is to investigate layer-structured (BN)x(C2)1-x semiconductor alloys with an emphasis on materials growth by metal organic chemical vapor deposition, basic material properties studies, and exploration of potential applications. (BN)x(C2)1-x semiconductor alloys represent a unique material system for exploring the evolution of optical properties from far infrared to deep ultraviolet and transport properties from insulator to semi-metal in the same crystal structure. Research tasks include the probe of fundamental optical and electrical properties such as the energy bandgap and its variation with temperature and alloy composition, free, bound, and localized exciton transitions, impurity energy levels, feasibility of n- and p-type conductivity control, and carrier transport properties.
Non-technical Description: The project trains postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of novel materials growth, characterization, nano-fabrication techniques and material/device processing using the state-of-the-art facilities. (BN)x(C2)1-x material system has the potential to complement nitride wide-bandgap semiconductors and carbon based nanostructured materials and enable the realization of chip-scale multi-spectral light sources and detectors and full spectral multi-junction solar cells. Ultimately, the materials developed could have a major impact on energy, medical, security, and communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
III-N wide bandgap semiconductors have contributed on the grandest scale to many technological advances including UV/blue/green/white light emitting diodes (LEDs), UV/blue/green laser diodes, UV/visible detectors, and high temperature/power transistors.  These devices are broadly used in smart phones, readers, lighting, displays, medical devices, satellites and power grids. Meanwhile, due to the recent extraordinary development in graphene research, carbon based layer-structured materials appear to be very promising for creating many novel applications.  Among them, the two most common layer-structured materials are graphite (carbon atoms with hexagonal structure) and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN). Both h-BN and graphite (C) are layer-structured materials with very similar lattice parameters and crystalline structures. This aim of this project is to study the feasibility of epitaxial thin film growth and the fundamental properties of layer-structured boron nitride carbon semiconductor alloys (BN)x(C2)1-x, which have the potential to complement nitride wide bandgap semiconductors and carbon/based nanostructured materials.

During the project period, we have acquired the basic growth processes for producing wafer scale homogenous films of (BN)x(C2)1-x alloys by metal organic vapor deposition technique and to characterized the properties of the grown films. Our experimental results have shown that homogeneous (BN)1-x(C2)x alloys in the layer structured phase in both (BN)-rich and C-rich sides have been successfully synthesized at 1300 0C. Bandgap and electrical conductivity variations with the alloy composition have been demonstrated. Novel device applications based on these materials including deep UV light emitting devices, detectors, and thermal neutron detectors for nuclear threat sensing have been explored. We have also identified possible processing routes to further enhance the overall material quality of these alloys. The results of this project open up new realms of science and technology. These alloy materials represent a unique system for exploring the evolution of optical properties from far infrared (IR) to deep ultraviolet (UV) and electrical properties from insulator to semiconductor in the same crystal structure. The successful realization of these materials in wafer scale will also lead to unprecedented applications, such as on-chip optical sources and detectors functioning in a spectral range from far IR to deep UV wavelengths. These devices will impact areas in energy, medical, security, communication, and entertainment. The program has trained postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of novel material growth, characterization, nano-fabrication techniques and material/device processing using the state-of-the-art facilities. Opportunities have been provided to junior researchers to attend national conferences and workshops.
